UX / UI flow

Converting an outdated webpage to a modern user-friendly site

Starting web site: www.paradiseyogurt.com
(frozen yogurt retail store)
The main goal was to do a significant improvement in user experience. In order to reach that goal following stages of designing proses were performed:
- Needs Analysis and Content Audit
- Creating user personas profile
- Competitive analysis of the three competitors on a market
- Developing a site map
- Performing cart sort and reverse cart sort
- Evolving results of cart sorting into Standardization Grid
- Defining user flow
- Prototyping (low, middle and high-fidelity prototypes of webpages)
The project was performed as a group class assignment of the Front End Web Development Certificate Program.

Needs Analysis & Content Audit

Need analysis and content audit is a research that was performed to reveal the major problems. Performing deep research is s a key stage to approach solutions for effective design.

Current Site is dated, poorly designed, and not user-friendly.

Desired Outcome: An aesthetically pleasing website that is easy to navigate. Something that accurately portrays the brand, a tropical-themed dessert oasis.

Voice and Tone: Fun and cheerful yet direct and informative.

User Persona Profile

A user persona is a fictional character created to represent a user type that might use a website. During the design process, it's important to refer to the user persona with an idea to satisfy customer needs.

Because frozen yogurt as a product has a wide audience, we created 4 potential persona profiles. Some UX specialists recommend having 1 or 2 personas only to focus on your specific target audience. As a result, it eases the designers' decision making. That's why we also focused on one user profile only.

Competitors

We analyzed three competitors websites:

- Menchies.com

- Yogurtland.com

- Pinkberry.com

They were very similar in design and tone with few variations. All were aesthetically pleasing, responsive and fairly easy to navigate.

Competitive Analysis

Example of features that influenced our website design by one of the competitors (Pinkberry):
- Very bright colors, lots of images of the frozen yogurt, most of the images have a combination of yogurt and people on it. Digital marketing studies show that images with people on it receive more engagement on social media and the web in general.
- Probably this website got most of the view on a mobile screen. That's why it's very mobile-friendly. Also promotional material contains a lot of images of the mobile screen with a pinkberry.com website on it.

Site Map

The original website is one long page. Before the card sort was conducted, we knew that we would have to divide the website into separate pages.

Our site map seperates the contents into logical sections.

Cart Sort

With a purpose to establish a better user experience, we asked 6 participants where they would expect to find certain information located on the website. Below you can find example of questions asked and most popular response:
- "Where do you get hours?"
Most participants chose to put it under the “about us” page.

- "Where would you find GrubHub service to make an order?"
Most participants chose to put this info under “delivery.”

Giving participants these tasks allowed us to determine where the user expected to find particular information.

Reverse Cart Sort & Standardization Grid

Reverse Sort:
- The reverse card sort helped flesh out what we already knew, that the information needed to be better organized and that some content was unnecessary and needed to be removed.
- The reverse card sort prioritized content and determined where the information needed to be located.

After Cart Sort and Reverse Cart Sort have been performed, all gained information we systematized into the standardization grid.

It helped to see patterns of the user behavior and improve site map of the website.

User Flow

UX flows display the complete path a user takes when using a product.

On a provided example you can see how the user reaches the goal: find out about the history of the business.

Application used: Adobe XD.

Low Fidelity Prototype

Low fidelity prototype is a first mock-up variation of the selected web-page layouts.

Creating wireframes as a simple set of sketches allowed us to agree for the initial position of the elements on a page.

After that, we voted which one we like the most. Based on that design we created more detailed wireframes and comps.

Wireframes

Wireframes are like blueprints in architecture. The purpose is to communicate the order, structure, layout, navigation and organization of content.

It's not to communicate visual design aspects such as imagery, color, and typography.

For that reason, we have performed it in black and white.

Application used: Adobe XD.

Comps

While creating Comps we employ brand consistency and aesthetics to convert solid wireframes into compelling mockups.

The chosen color palette represents the spirit of tropical paradise.

Application used: Adobe Photoshop/Illustrator

Copmare Results

The picture presents designs of the old and new versions of the web site in comparison. Significant changes were applied such as:

  • Simplified menu were created.
  • The header links to About, Menu, Delivery, Catering.
  • Menu has sub-categories: Frozen Yogurt, Smoothies, Frozen Pies, etc.
  • Delivery leads to external links; grubhub and postmates.
  • The footer links to merchandise, franchise, and jobs.
  • This architecture has more sections than the original website, which is one bulky, hard to navigate page. We decided to create uniformed pages so the information is easy to find and read.
  • etc.

A / B testing

For the scope of this particular UX project, creating a Comps were a final stage.

Though to make this digital product even more attractive and user-friendly, the next stage could be a A/B testing.

Developing product based on results of A/B testing increases the achievement of targeted actions, conversion and gets more profit.
